subTitleBlogPost: Sharing my journey in code, design, and discoveries

blogPostCards.title: Warp
blogPostCards.content:
I've been using Warp for a while now and I have to say, it's the only terminal I ever need. It was first released for Mac, and I discovered it when I had issues with my built-in terminal and was looking for a new one. That's when I found Warp.
At that time, it was only available for Mac, and I had been checking for updates for Windows from time to time. A few weeks ago, it finally came to Windows, and I was thrilled. The installation process was incredibly simple on both Mac and Windows. Sure, it offers different themes and customizable text options, but the absolute best part is that I can now save my terminal commands. I have many commands in my head, but not all of them, and some I don't use that often. For example, when I need to change a commit message. Sure, Google can help, but now I can save those commands and access them with one click when I need them.

Another amazing feature is the built-in AI, which lets me write and ask for specific commands, and it actually explains what the command does. Another thing I love is that I don't have to use the arrow keys to navigate - I can simply use my mouse. If I notice a typo, I can click on it and change it directly. It's so much easier.

I really love it. It's a must-have for any developer who appreciates the power of the terminal, just like I do.

blogPostCards.title: Printagon Order Form
blogPostCards.titleDescription: Creating a new order form for Printagon
blogPostCards.content: Right now, I'm working on a new Printagon order form. I had a meeting with a client to discuss their needs before implementing the feature. Which fields should be mandatory. After the meeting, I started working on the form. So now I'm working on the backend API, which will be completed soon before I move on to the frontend and create the reusable input form with input fields and text area.
